Engineer / Engineering Trainee (Equipment Reliability) at Bruce Power: Job Posting Start Date: 2025-04-24Job Posting End Date: 2025-05-08At Bruce Power, you’ll experience the meaningful work of advancing Ontario’s clean energy future and medical isotope innovation while contributing to a culture of excellence. Step into an inclusive and dynamic environment that values collaboration, encourages bold ideas and empowers you to make a real difference.From safely delivering clean, reliable power to families and businesses across the province and cancer-fighting medical isotopes around the world to supporting challenging and innovative nuclear projects like our multi-year Life Extension Program, we offer interesting and impactful opportunities. Ongoing training and development are part of every job, providing constant growth and skill-building potential.Be a part of the team — our future is bright!In support of achieving excellence and business results through safe, reliable operations, our Equipment Reliability Program section of the Engineering Support Department is currently hiring for an Engineer / Engineering Trainee.This is a permanent, full-time position which offers a competitive benefits, compensation and pension package and is located on site in Tiverton, Ontario.What will you be responsible for?As a member of the team, you will report to the Section Manager, Engineering. 🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

"We can just hire a few software engineers and train them on LLMs."Haha I hear this a lot from fast-growing startups.It sounds good in theory.In practice? It rarely works.Why?-Fine tuning LLMs isn’t just writing better code, it’s a deep mix of ML theory, systems optimization, and data intuition.-Building an efficient LLM stack involves tokenization, embeddings, vector search, retrieval pipelines, and custom evaluation metrics.-LLM engineering isn't a “learn on the job” role at scale.Companies who treat LLM engineering like software engineering usually realize after 6+ months lost that expertise matters from day one.Hiring right the first time isn’t optional. It’s survival.hashtag#AIHiring hashtag#LLM hashtag#DeepTech hashtag#StartupHiring hashtag#Founders hashtag#HiringStrategy

DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: •	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. •	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). •	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. •	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. •	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. •	Automate release pipelines and testing. •	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  •	Excellent communication skills. •	Proven leadership and team management skills. •	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. •	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. •	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). •	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). •	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. •	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. •	Experience with SQL and SQL server. •	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). •	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  •	Competitive Salary •	Comprehensive Benefits Package •	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

Law firms, in-house legal teams, legal tech startups, and compliance divisions are hiring professionals who understand legal processes, automation tools, business systems, and data-driven decision-making.Yet in many parts of the world—including India—this role is still emerging.So why did I create a roadmap and course for it?✅ Because legal professionals today need more than just domain knowledge. ✅ Because law firms are undergoing digital transformation, but lack professionals who can translate legal needs into business and tech solutions. ✅ Because roles like Legal Engineers, Legal Ops, and Legal Transformation Analysts are going to be mainstream in the next 2–3 years.But most importantly— I built this because I’ve seen law students, lawyers, and business analysts struggle to find a niche where they can grow without choosing between law and technology.This role is not just the future. It’s the present—just not evenly distributed yet.💡 If you’re curious about how this role works, what it looks like in real life, and how to step into it—I’ve built something that might help. DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

"We can just hire a few software engineers and train them on LLMs."Haha I hear this a lot from fast-growing startups.It sounds good in theory.In practice? It rarely works.Why?-Fine tuning LLMs isn’t just writing better code, it’s a deep mix of ML theory, systems optimization, and data intuition.-Building an efficient LLM stack involves tokenization, embeddings, vector search, retrieval pipelines, and custom evaluation metrics.-LLM engineering isn't a “learn on the job” role at scale.Companies who treat LLM engineering like software engineering usually realize after 6+ months lost that expertise matters from day one.Hiring right the first time isn’t optional. It’s survival.hashtag#AIHiring hashtag#LLM hashtag#DeepTech hashtag#StartupHiring hashtag#Founders hashtag#HiringStrategy

DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: •	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. •	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). •	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. •	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. •	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. •	Automate release pipelines and testing. •	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  •	Excellent communication skills. •	Proven leadership and team management skills. •	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. •	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. •	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). •	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). •	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. •	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. •	Experience with SQL and SQL server. •	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). •	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  •	Competitive Salary •	Comprehensive Benefits Package •	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: •	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. •	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). •	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. •	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. •	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. •	Automate release pipelines and testing. •	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  •	Excellent communication skills. •	Proven leadership and team management skills. •	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. •	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. •	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). •	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). •	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. •	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. •	Experience with SQL and SQL server. •	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). •	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  •	Competitive Salary •	Comprehensive Benefits Package •	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

"We can just hire a few software engineers and train them on LLMs."Haha I hear this a lot from fast-growing startups.It sounds good in theory.In practice? It rarely works.Why?-Fine tuning LLMs isn’t just writing better code, it’s a deep mix of ML theory, systems optimization, and data intuition.-Building an efficient LLM stack involves tokenization, embeddings, vector search, retrieval pipelines, and custom evaluation metrics.-LLM engineering isn't a “learn on the job” role at scale.Companies who treat LLM engineering like software engineering usually realize after 6+ months lost that expertise matters from day one.Hiring right the first time isn’t optional. It’s survival.hashtag#AIHiring hashtag#LLM hashtag#DeepTech hashtag#StartupHiring hashtag#Founders hashtag#HiringStrategy

DATA ANALYSISWHAT ARE WE ANALYSING AND WHY.AI Overview+6Improving data analysis in education involves establishing clear goals, investing in training, ensuring data quality.This includes defining specific outcomes to guide data collection and analysis, providing educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, and implementing practices to maintain accurate and reliable data. Key Strategies for Improving Data Analysis in Education: Define Clear Goals and Questions:Identify the specific questions you want to answer and the outcomes you hope to achieve through data analysis.  Choose Appropriate Data Types and Sources:Select relevant data sources, such as learning management systems, student information systems, and assessment platforms, and ensure data is integrated and standardized for analysis.  Use Suitable Data Analysis Tools and Techniques:Utilize tools designed for educational data analysis, including descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and qualitative analysis techniques.  Visualize and Communicate Data Findings:Present data in a clear and accessible manner, using visuals like charts and graphs, to effectively communicate insights to stakeholders.  Reflect and Act on Data Insights:Encourage educators to reflect on data insights and use them to inform teaching practices and personalize learning experiences.  Learn who Others are and Stay Updated:Connect with other educators, attend workshops, and stay informed about new developments in data analysis and educational technology.  Encourage Collaboration:Foster teamwork among educators, IT professionals, and data analysts to leverage diverse expertise.  Invest in Training:Provide educators with the skills needed to interpret and act on data insights, including data literacy, data analysis techniques, and data visualization.  Ensure Data Quality:Implement practices to maintain accurate and reliable data, such as data cleansing and validation.  Use Advanced Tools:Leverage technology designed for educational data analysis, including machine learning algorithms for personalized learning experiences.  Establish Data Cycles:Calendarize cyclic data collection, processing, and use to ensure consistent and effective data analysis.  Develop and Refine Data Metrics:Improve the quality and range of data captured to gain a more comprehensive understanding of student learning.  Provide Teacher Ownership:Empower teachers to use data and track their own impact on student learning.  Construct a Data Warehouse:Centralize data from various sources to facilitate tracking and understanding connections between different data points. Implementing these strategies, educational institutions  improve their data analysis, leading to informed decisions, personalized learning experiences, and improved student outcomes.

🚀 AI Supercomputers: A Double-Edged Sword of Progress and Power Consumption 🤖⚡A groundbreaking study by researchers from Georgetown, Epoch AI, and Rand has unveiled the exponential growth trajectory of AI data centers worldwide, raising critical questions about sustainability and resource allocation in the tech industry.Key findings:• Computational performance of AI data centers is more than doubling annually• Hardware costs increasing 1.9x each year• Power requirements climbing 2x annuallyBy 2030, the leading AI data center could require:• 2 million AI chips• $200 billion in construction costs• 9 gigawatts of power (equivalent to 9 nuclear reactors)While tech giants like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google are investing billions to expand their AI infrastructure, this rapid growth comes with significant challenges:1. Environmental Impact: Despite improvements in energy efficiency, the increasing power demands may strain renewable sources and lead to greater reliance on fossil fuels.2. Resource Allocation: The massive investments required for these data centers raise questions about the distribution of resources in the tech industry and beyond.3. Geographic Concentration: With 75% of AI supercomputing power hosted in the US, followed by 15% in China, there are implications for global tech competition and data sovereignty.4. Market Dynamics: Recent scaling back of data center projects by some hyperscalers suggests growing industry concerns about unsustainable expansion.As we navigate this AI revolution, the challenge lies in balancing technological advancement with environmental sustainability and infrastructure capabilities. How can we harness the power of AI while ensuring responsible growth?What are your thoughts on this exponential growth in AI computing? How can the industry address these challenges?Read more about this crucial development in AI infrastructure: https://lnkd.in/dE77-XnUhashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#DataCenters hashtag#TechSustainability hashtag#FutureOfComputing

Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work. Required Skills and Experience:  •	Excellent communication skills. •	Proven leadership and team management skills. •	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. •	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. •	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). •	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). •	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. •	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. •	Experience with SQL and SQL server. •	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). •	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  •	Competitive Salary •	Comprehensive Benefits Package •	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

"We can just hire a few software engineers and train them on LLMs."Haha I hear this a lot from fast-growing startups.It sounds good in theory.In practice? It rarely works.Why?-Fine tuning LLMs isn’t just writing better code, it’s a deep mix of ML theory, systems optimization, and data intuition.-Building an efficient LLM stack involves tokenization, embeddings, vector search, retrieval pipelines, and custom evaluation metrics.-LLM engineering isn't a “learn on the job” role at scale.Companies who treat LLM engineering like software engineering usually realize after 6+ months lost that expertise matters from day one.Hiring right the first time isn’t optional.
